<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_di1112_1_17"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="di1112_management_s_discussion_and_an__man03466"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_di1112_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="di1112_controls_and_procedures"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_di1112_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Controls and Procedures    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;An evaluation was performed under the supervision and with the participation of the Company's management, including the Chief Executive Officer ("CEO") and Chief
Financial Officer ("CFO"), of the effectiveness of the design and operation of the Company's disclosure controls and procedures within 90&nbsp;days before the filing date of this annual report.
Based on that evaluation, the Company's management, including the CEO and CFO, concluded that the Company's disclosure controls and procedures were effective. There have been no significant changes in
the Company's internal controls or in other factors that could significantly affect internal controls subsequent to their evaluation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
intend to review and evaluate the design and effectiveness of our disclosure controls and procedures on an ongoing basis and to improve our controls and procedures over time and to
correct any deficiencies that we may discover in the future. Our goal is to ensure that our senior management has timely access to all material financial and non-financial information
concerning our business. While we believe the present design of our disclosure controls and procedures is effective to achieve our goal, future events affecting our business may cause us to modify our
disclosure controls and procedures. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="di1112_critical_accounting_policies"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_di1112_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Critical Accounting Policies    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The preparation of financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make a
number of judgments, estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amount of assets, liabilities, income and expenses in our Consolidated Financial Statements and accompanying notes. We believe
that the judgments, estimates and assumptions used in the preparation of our Consolidated Financial Statements are appropriate given the factual circumstances as of December&nbsp;31, 2002. However,
given the sensitivity of our Consolidated Financial Statements to these critical accounting policies, the use of other judgments, estimates and assumptions could result in material differences in our
results of operations or financial condition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Various
elements of our accounting policies, by their nature, are inherently subject to estimation techniques, valuation assumptions and other subjective assessments. In particular, we
have identified four policies that, due to the judgments, estimates and assumptions inherent in those policies, are critical to an </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>17</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=19,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=485657,FOLIO='17',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DI1112A.;38',USER='LSTARKE',CD='14-MAR-2003;16:51' -->
<A NAME="page_di1112_1_18"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
understanding of our Consolidated Financial Statements. The table below represents information about the nature of and rationale for the Company's critical accounting policies: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=9 ALIGN="CENTER"><HR NOSHADE><BR></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="14%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Critical<BR>
Accounting<BR>
Policy<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="16%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Consolidated<BR>
Statements<BR>
of Financial<BR>
Position Caption<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="16%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Consolidated<BR>
Statements of<BR>
Income Caption<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="29%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Nature of Estimates Required<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="15%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Reference<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=9 ALIGN="CENTER"><HR NOSHADE><BR></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="14%"><FONT SIZE=2>Fair value of mortgage servicing rights</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="16%"><FONT SIZE=2>Mortgage servicing rights</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="16%"><FONT SIZE=2>Home loan mortgage banking income (expense): Impairment adjustment</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="29%"><FONT SIZE=2>Determining the fair value of our MSR requires us to formulate conclusions about anticipated changes in future market conditions, including interest rates. Our loan servicing portfolio is subject to prepayment risk, which
subjects our MSR to impairment risk.<BR>
The fair value of our MSR is estimated using a discounted cash flow model. The discounted cash flow model estimates the present value of the future net cash flows of the servicing portfolio based on various factors, such as servicing costs, expected
prepayment speeds and discount rates, about which management must make assumptions based on future expectations. While the Company's model estimates a value, the specific value used is based on a variety of factors, such as documented observable data
and anticipated changes in market conditions. All of the assumptions are based on standards used by market participants in valuing MSR. The reasonableness of management's assumptions about these factors is confirmed through quarterly independent
broker surveys. Independent appraisals of the fair value of our servicing portfolio are obtained periodically, but not less frequently than annually, and are used by management to evaluate the reasonableness of the fair value conclusions.</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="15%"><FONT SIZE=2>Limitations to the measurement of MSR fair value are described in the subsequent section of Management's Discussion and Analysis&nbsp;&#150; "Earnings Performance" on page&nbsp;29. See the key economic assumptions and the
sensitivity of the current fair value for home loans' MSR to immediate changes in those assumptions in Note&nbsp;5 to the Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#150; "Mortgage Banking Activities."</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=9><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="14%"><FONT SIZE=2>Rate lock commitments</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="16%"><FONT SIZE=2>Other assets</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="16%"><FONT SIZE=2>Home loan mortgage banking income (expense): Gain from mortgage loans</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="29%"><FONT SIZE=2>The Company enters into commitments to make loans whereby the interest rate on the loan is set prior to funding (rate lock commitments). Rate lock commitments on mortgage loans that are intended to be sold are considered
to be derivatives, and therefore, they are recorded at fair value. In measuring the fair value of rate lock commitments, the amount of the expected servicing rights is included in the valuation. This value is calculated using the same methodologies
as are used to value the Company's MSR, adjusted using an anticipated fallout factor for loan commitments that will never be funded. This policy of recognizing the value of the derivative has the effect of recognizing the gain from mortgage loans
before the loans are sold.</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="15%"><FONT SIZE=2>See further discussion in the subsequent section of Management's Discussion and Analysis&nbsp;&#150; "Earnings Performance" on page&nbsp;29.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=9><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>18</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=20,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=32292,FOLIO='18',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DI1112A.;38',USER='LSTARKE',CD='14-MAR-2003;16:51' -->
<A NAME="page_di1112_1_19"> </A>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=9 ALIGN="CENTER"><HR NOSHADE><BR></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="14%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Critical<BR>
Accounting<BR>
Policy<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="17%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Consolidated<BR>
Statements<BR>
of Financial<BR>
Position Caption<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="16%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Consolidated<BR>
Statements of<BR>
Income Caption<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="29%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Nature of Estimates Required<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="15%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Reference<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=9 ALIGN="CENTER"><HR NOSHADE><BR></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="14%"><FONT SIZE=2>Allowance for loan and lease losses</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="17%"><FONT SIZE=2>Allowance for loan and lease losses</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="16%"><FONT SIZE=2>Provision for loan and lease losses</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="29%"><FONT SIZE=2>The allowance for loan and lease losses represents management's estimate of credit losses inherent in the Company's loan and lease portfolios as of the balance sheet date. The estimation of the allowance is based on a
variety of factors, including past loan loss experience, adverse situations that have occurred but are not yet known that may affect the borrower's ability to repay, the estimated value of the underlying collateral and general economic conditions.
The Company's methodology for assessing the adequacy of the allowance includes the evaluation of three distinct elements: the formula allowance, the specific allowance and the unallocated allowance. The ultimate recovery of all loans is susceptible
to future market factors beyond the Company's control.</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="15%"><FONT SIZE=2>The estimates and judgments are described in further detail in the subsequent sections of Management's Discussion and Analysis&nbsp;&#150; "Asset Quality" on page&nbsp;43 and in Note&nbsp;1 to the Consolidated Financial
Statements&nbsp;&#150; "Summary of Significant Accounting Policies."</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=9><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="14%"><FONT SIZE=2>Net periodic pension expense</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="17%"><FONT SIZE=2>Other assets</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="16%"><FONT SIZE=2>Compensation and benefits</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="29%"><FONT SIZE=2>The net periodic pension expense is actuarially determined using assumed discount rates, assumed rates of compensation increase and expected return on assets. These assumptions are ultimately determined by management.<BR>
The discount rate is determined using Moody's Aa spot rate as of year end. The compensation rate is determined by reviewing the Company's salary increases each year along with reviewing industry averages. The expected return on assets represents
management's expectation of the average rate of earnings on the funds invested to provide for the benefits included in the projected benefit obligation.</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="15%"><FONT SIZE=2>The impact to compensation and benefits expense if certain assumptions are changed is discussed in the subsequent section of Management's Discussion and Analysis&nbsp;&#150; "Liquidity" on page&nbsp;53.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=9><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management has discussed the development and selection of these critical accounting policies with the Audit Committee of our Board of Directors.
In addition, there are other complex accounting standards that require the Company to employ significant judgment in interpreting and applying certain of the principles prescribed by those standards.
These judgments include, but are not limited to, the determination of whether a financial instrument or other contract meets the definition of a derivative in accordance with Statement No.&nbsp;133, </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Derivative
Instruments and Hedging Activities</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, and the applicable hedge deferral criteria. These policies and the judgments, estimates
and assumptions are described in greater detail in subsequent sections of Management's Discussion and Analysis and in Note&nbsp;1 to the Consolidated Financial Statements &#150; "Summary of
Significant Accounting Policies." </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>19</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Restated
for all stock splits.</FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="di1112_significant_transactions"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_di1112_5"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Significant Transactions    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion and analysis should be read in conjunction with the Consolidated Financial Statements and Notes thereto presented elsewhere in this
report. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2002, the Company completed three acquisitions. On January&nbsp;4, 2002, we completed our acquisition of New York-based Dime Bancorp,&nbsp;Inc. The aggregate
purchase price of Dime was approximately $5.3 billion. The acquisition of Dime added approximately $31&nbsp;billion to our asset base, including approximately $22&nbsp;billion in loans, and
increased our deposit base by approximately $15&nbsp;billion. The acquisition of Dime also significantly contributed to the growth in our mortgage banking business, resulting in a
$926&nbsp;million increase to our MSR balance and a $49.24&nbsp;billion increase in our portfolio of loans serviced for others. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
two transactions during 2002, we purchased for cash HomeSide Lending,&nbsp;Inc., the U.S. mortgage unit of National Australia Bank Limited. The aggregate purchase price of HomeSide
was $2.45&nbsp;billion. The acquisition of HomeSide added approximately $1&nbsp;billion in loans held for sale, approximately $960&nbsp;million in net MSR and approximately $130&nbsp;billion
to our portfolio of loans serviced for others. We also acquired a proprietary loan servicing platform, which we intend to make our primary loan servicing platform. In addition we assumed
$760&nbsp;million in long-term debt and $750&nbsp;million in other liabilities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company also sold servicing rights during 2002, which, together with high amortization levels and impairment that were attributable to low interest rates during the year, resulted in
a $900&nbsp;million decrease in our net MSR balance. These sales were part of the Company's strategy to actively manage the size of our MSR while still retaining the customer relationships. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>20</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=22,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=1036176,FOLIO='20',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DI1112A.;38',USER='LSTARKE',CD='14-MAR-2003;16:51' -->
<A NAME="page_di1112_1_21"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also
during 2002, the Company significantly increased its level of deposits primarily due to the growth in Platinum Account balances, which increased from $9.40&nbsp;billion at
December&nbsp;31, 2001 to $50.20&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2002. The increase in deposits resulted in a reduction in our wholesale borrowings, which declined from $105.32&nbsp;billion
at December&nbsp;31, 2001 to $69.23&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2001, we completed three acquisitions. On January&nbsp;31, we acquired the mortgage operations of The PNC Financial Services Group,&nbsp;Inc. for approximately $7.0 billion.
On February&nbsp;9, we acquired Texas-based Bank United Corp. for approximately $1.4 billion, and on June&nbsp;1, we acquired Fleet Mortgage Corp., a unit of FleetBoston Financial Corp., and
certain other mortgage lending operations of Fleet National Bank for approximately $7.5 billion. Substantially due to these acquisitions, our loan serviced for others portfolio grew from
$85.88&nbsp;billion at January&nbsp;1, 2001 to $382.50&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2001 and our loans held for sale increased from $3.40&nbsp;billion to $26.58&nbsp;billion.
Correspondingly, the MSR associated with our servicing portfolio increased from $1.02&nbsp;billion at January&nbsp;1, 2001 to $6.24&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2001. The acquisition of
Bank United also increased our deposit base by $8.09&nbsp;billion and added approximately $12&nbsp;billion to our loans held in portfolio. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Variances
in the amounts reported on the Consolidated Statements of Income between 2002, 2001 and prior years and on the Consolidated Statements of Financial Condition between 2002 and
2001 are partially attributable to the results from the aforementioned acquisitions as the results from those operations are included prospectively from the date of acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>21</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=23,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=195463,FOLIO='21',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DI1112A.;38',USER='LSTARKE',CD='14-MAR-2003;16:51' -->
<A NAME="page_di1112_1_22"> </A>
<BR>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> Ratios and Other Supplemental Data  </B></FONT></P>
</UL>
<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="80%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=3 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=8 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Year Ended December 31,</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=3 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2002</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>

<TD WIDTH="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="48%"><FONT SIZE=2>Year end</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>34.53</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>32.70</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>35.38</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>The efficiency ratio is defined as noninterest expense, excluding amortization of goodwill, divided by total revenue (net interest
income and noninterest income).</FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Excludes unrealized net gain/loss on available-for-sale securities and derivatives, goodwill and intangible assets, but includes
MSR.</FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(3)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Estimate of what the total risk-based capital ratio would be if Washington Mutual, Inc. was a bank holding company that complies
with Federal Reserve Board capital requirements.</FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(4)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Excludes 18&nbsp;million shares held in escrow pending resolution of the Company's asserted right to the return of such
shares.</FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>22</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>The
average balance and yield on available-for-sale and held-to-maturity securities are based on average amortized cost balances. </FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Nonaccrual
loans are included in the average loan amounts outstanding. </FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(3)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Interest
income for loans held in portfolio includes amortization of net deferred loan origination costs of $259 million, $173 million, and $65 million for the years
ended December 31, 2002, 2001, and 2000. </FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(4)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Represents
loans to builders for the purpose of financing the acquisition, development and construction of single-family residences for sale. </FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(5)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Represents
construction loans made directly to the intended occupant of a single-family residence. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>23</FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>24</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=26,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=1019007,FOLIO='24',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DK1112A.;29',USER='CPULLIA',CD='13-MAR-2003;08:48' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1112_1_25"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The dollar amounts of interest income and interest expense fluctuate depending upon changes in interest rates and upon changes in the volume of
our interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities. Changes attributable to (i)&nbsp;changes in volume (changes in average outstanding balances multiplied by the prior period's rate),
(ii)&nbsp;changes in rate (changes in average interest rate multiplied by the prior period's volume), and (iii)&nbsp;changes in rate/volume (changes in rate times the change in volume) which were
allocated proportionately to the changes in volume and the changes in rate and included in the relevant column below were as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

loans to builders for the purpose of financing the acquisition, development and construction of single-family residences for sale. </FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Represents

<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=27,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=509659,FOLIO='25',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DK1112A.;29',USER='CPULLIA',CD='13-MAR-2003;08:48' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dm1112_1_26"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dm1112_earnings_performance"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm1112_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Earnings Performance    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Net Interest Income  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, net interest income increased $1.47&nbsp;billion, or 21% compared with the same period in 2001. Most of this
increase was attributable to the growth in average interest-earning assets, which increased primarily as a result of the Dime acquisition, and the expansion of the net interest margin, which increased
16 basis points during the year. The margin benefited from the full effect that the 475 basis point reduction in the Federal Funds rate in 2001 had on our wholesale borrowings, which reprice to market
interest levels more quickly than our interest-earning assets. After peaking in the first quarter of 2002, the net interest margin declined throughout the remainder of 2002, largely due to the
downward repricing of loans and debt securities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
interest expense on interest-bearing checking accounts experienced a significant increase in 2002 due to the growth of, and the rates offered on, Platinum Accounts. During the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, the average balance of Platinum Accounts was $34,018&nbsp;million, compared with $1,384&nbsp;million during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. The rates
offered on Platinum Accounts increased the average rate paid on interest-bearing checking accounts from 1.58% in 2001 to 2.55% in 2002. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the balance in Platinum Accounts
totaled $50.20&nbsp;billion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, net interest income increased $2.57&nbsp;billion, or 59%, compared with the same period in 2000. The increase in net interest income was
primarily due to a significant improvement in the net interest margin. The net interest margin was 3.32% for 2001, compared with 2.38% for 2000. As a result of the Federal Funds rate cuts that
occurred during 2001, the cost of our wholesale borrowings during 2001 was significantly lower than 2000. The increase in deposits, coupled with lower rates, also benefited the margin in 2001. An
increase in average interest-earning assets, primarily resulting from the addition of the Bank United loan portfolio and the mortgage banking operations of PNC and Fleet, also contributed to the
growth in net interest income. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
rate contracts, including embedded derivatives, held for asset/liability interest rate risk management purposes decreased net interest income by $407&nbsp;million for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. Interest rate contracts, including embedded derivatives, increased net interest income by $22&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 and by
$67&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>26</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Home Loan Mortgage Banking Income  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in home loan servicing fees for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 was the result of the increase in our loans serviced for others portfolio,
partially offset by a decline in the aggregate weighted average servicing fee. Our loans serviced for others portfolio increased from $382,500&nbsp;million at year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 to
$604,504&nbsp;million at year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 primarily as a result of the acquisition of Dime and HomeSide along with strong levels of salable home loan volume, in which we retain
the servicing relationship. The strong home loan volume during 2002 was primarily due to high refinancing volume, which was caused by very low mortgage rates and the expansion of our correspondent
lending activities, which resulted from the acquisition of Dime and HomeSide in 2002, and Fleet Mortgage in 2001. The increase in home loan servicing fees for 2001, as compared with 2000, was
substantially the result of the addition of the loan servicing portfolios of Bank United, PNC Mortgage and Fleet Mortgage. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>27</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<A NAME="page_dm1112_1_28"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
decrease in the weighted average servicing fee from 47 basis points at December&nbsp;31, 2001 to 40 basis points at December&nbsp;31, 2002 was primarily due to sales of servicing
rights, which decreased the net MSR balance by $997&nbsp;million, but had no impact on the unpaid principal balance of the loans serviced for others portfolio. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A
continued decrease in long-term mortgage rates during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001 led to higher anticipated prepayment rates, which resulted in MSR
impairment of $3,219&nbsp;million and $1,701&nbsp;million for 2002 and 2001, thereby increasing the MSR impairment allowance to $4,521&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and $1,714 million
at December&nbsp;31, 2001. Continued high volumes of actual prepayment activity during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, coupled with the growth in the MSR servicing portfolio,
resulted in higher MSR amortization, as compared with the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
measuring the impairment of MSR, we stratify the loans in our servicing portfolio primarily based on loan type and coupon rate. We measure MSR impairment by estimating the fair value
of each stratum. An impairment allowance for a stratum is recorded when, and in the amount by which, its fair value is less than its carrying value. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, we stratified the
loans in our servicing portfolio as follows: </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=30,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=956013,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DM1112A.;18',USER='TCHAN',CD='14-MAR-2003;02:44' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1112_1_29"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
rate bands are generally sorted into 150 basis point intervals. The Company will consider adding additional strata to our servicing portfolio if loans with coupon rates below
6.00% reach significant levels. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
value of our MSR asset is subject to prepayment risk. Future expected net cash flows from servicing a loan in our servicing portfolio will not be realized if the loan pays off
earlier than anticipated. Moreover, since most loans within our servicing portfolio do not contain penalty provisions for early payoff, we will not receive a corresponding economic benefit if the loan
pays off earlier than expected. MSR represent the discounted present value of the future net cash flows we expect to receive from our servicing portfolio. Accordingly, prepayment risk subjects our MSR
to impairment risk. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
estimate fair value of each MSR stratum using a discounted cash flow model. The discounted cash flow model estimates the present value of the future net cash flows of the servicing
portfolio based on various factors, such as servicing costs, expected prepayment speeds and discount rates, about which management must make assumptions based on future expectations. While the
Company's model estimates a value, the specific value used is based on a variety of factors, such as documented observable data and anticipated changes in market conditions. All the assumptions are
based on standards used by market participants in valuing MSR. The reasonableness of management's assumptions about these factors is confirmed through quarterly independent broker surveys. Independent
appraisals of the fair value of our servicing portfolio are obtained periodically, but not less frequently than annually, and are used by management to evaluate the reasonableness of the fair value
conclusions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
methodology for estimating the fair value of MSR is highly sensitive to changes in assumptions. For example, our determination of fair value uses anticipated prepayment speeds.
Actual prepayment experience may differ and any difference may have a material effect on the MSR fair value. Changes in fair value based on a variation in assumptions generally cannot be extrapolated
because the relationship of the change in assumption to the change in fair value may not be linear. Thus, any measurement of MSR fair value is limited by the conditions existing and assumptions made
as of a particular point in time. Those assumptions may not be appropriate if they are applied to a different point in time. Refer to "Market Risk Management" for discussion of how MSR prepayment risk
is managed and to Note&nbsp;1 to the Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#150; "Summary of Significant Accounting Policies" for further discussion of how MSR impairment is measured. For
a quantitative analysis of key economic assumptions used in measuring the fair value of MSR, and a sensitivity analysis based on changes to those assumptions, see Note&nbsp;5 to the Consolidated
Financial Statements&nbsp;&#150; "Mortgage Banking Activities." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
continuing high volume of refinancing activity allowed us to generate strong levels of salable home loan volume during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. Additionally, the
Company enters into commitments to make loans whereby the interest rate on the loan is set prior to funding (rate lock commitments). Rate lock commitments on mortgage loans that are intended to be
sold are considered to be derivatives. Therefore, they are recorded, at fair value, in other assets on the Consolidated Statements of Financial Condition with changes in fair value recorded in gain
from mortgage loans on the Consolidated Statements of Income. In measuring the fair value of rate lock commitments, the amount of the expected servicing rights is included in the valuation. This value
is calculated using the same methodologies as are used to value the Company's MSR, adjusted using an anticipated fallout factor for loan commitments that will never be funded. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This
policy of recognizing the value of the derivative has the effect of recognizing the gain from mortgage loans before the loans are sold. The fair value of rate lock commitments on
the Consolidated Statements of Financial Condition at December 31, 2002 and 2001 for which the underlying loans had not been funded was $473 million and $3 million. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
FASB staff or the Emerging Issues Task Force may issue additional guidance on this matter. Depending on what, if any, additional guidance is issued, the timing of the gain
recognition inherent within our rate lock commitments could be delayed, possibly until the date that the anticipated loans are sold. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=31,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=4905,FOLIO='29',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DM1112A.;18',USER='TCHAN',CD='14-MAR-2003;02:44' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1112_1_30"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
Generally, loans held for sale are sold within 60 to 120 days after the initial recognition of the rate lock commitment. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rate
lock commitment volume totaled $236.05&nbsp;billion for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, compared with $134.16&nbsp;billion for the same period in 2001. The total
notional amounts of rate lock commitments outstanding, including an anticipated fallout factor, at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and December&nbsp;31, 2001 were $26.97&nbsp;billion and
$12.59&nbsp;billion. The high levels of rate lock commitment volume resulted in gain from mortgage loans of $1,280&nbsp;million during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 compared with
$963&nbsp;million during the same period in 2001. Gain from mortgage loans for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 increased compared with 2000 as a result of higher levels of loan volume caused
by low mortgage interest rates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Government
National Mortgage Association ("GNMA") pool buy-out income was $319&nbsp;million for 2002. Beginning in 2002, the Company began to regularly exercise its buy-back rights
under the terms of its contracts with GNMA. The Company has the right to repurchase certain loans that are part of GNMA securitization pools before they have reached nonperforming status. In one part
of the Company's program, loans that have been 30 days past due for three consecutive months (referred to as "rolling 30 loans") are repurchased from GNMA and then resold in the secondary market. In
the other, loans that have missed three consecutive payments are likewise purchased and resold. These loans are collectively referred to as Early Buy-Out Loans. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gain
from the sale of these loans was $126&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. In the future, the Company will not have the option of repurchasing "rolling 30
loans" from pools created after January&nbsp;1, 2003, but will continue to make such purchases from previously created pools. The Company does not expect this change to have a significant impact on
its results of operations in 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally,
as part of its normal Federal Housing Administration and Department of Veterans Affairs lending program, the Company repurchases defaulted loans from GNMA and undertakes
collection and, if necessary, foreclosure proceedings with respect to those loans. Upon completion of the foreclosure, the Company can also submit a claim to either the Federal Housing Administration
or the Department of Veterans Affairs for payment on the insurance or guarantee, as the case may be, issued
by that agency. The portion of the recovery which is attributed to interest income owed to the Company is also recorded in this category. That interest income, together with interest income on the
Early Buy-Out Loans was $193&nbsp;million for 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Loan
related income increased during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001. A significant portion of this increase was due to increased late charges on the loans serviced for
others and loan prepayment fees on certain adjustable-rate mortgages with prepayment penalty provisions. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gain
from sale of originated mortgage-backed securities during the first quarter of 2001 included gains from the sale of adjustable-rate mortgage loans that were securitized
in the fourth quarter of 2000 and other mortgage-backed securities that were securitized in earlier periods. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<A NAME="page_dm1112_1_31"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
total amount of income from MSR risk management instruments offset MSR impairment and higher levels of MSR amortization that resulted from high loan prepayment activity. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revaluation
gain from derivatives is the earnings impact of the changes in fair value from certain derivatives where the Company has not attempted to achieve hedge accounting treatment
under Statement No.&nbsp;133. The significant increase in the revaluation gain from derivatives was due to the Company decreasing its reliance on investment securities during 2002 by shifting to a
blend of investment securities and derivatives. These derivatives were mostly used for MSR risk management purposes. The total notional amount of these MSR risk management derivatives at
December&nbsp;31, 2002 was $41.97&nbsp;billion with a combined fair value of $3.03&nbsp;billion, compared with zero at December&nbsp;31, 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
settlement income from certain interest-rate swaps represents the income from interest rate swaps where the Company has not attempted to achieve hedge accounting
treatment under Statement No.&nbsp;133. These swaps predominantly consisted of receive-fixed interest rate swaps, which were used as MSR risk management derivatives. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the
total notional amount of these receive-fixed interest-rate swaps was $17.92&nbsp;billion, compared with zero at December&nbsp;31, 2001. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> All Other Noninterest Income Analysis  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in depositor and other retail banking fees for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 was primarily due to higher levels of checking fees that
resulted from an increased number of noninterest-bearing checking accounts in comparison with the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 and an increase in fees from debit card services. The number of
these accounts at December&nbsp;31, 2002 totaled over 5.8&nbsp;million, an increase of more than 846,000 from December&nbsp;31, 2001. This increase included approximately 200,000
noninterest-bearing checking accounts acquired from Dime during the first quarter of 2002. The increase in depositor and other retail banking fees for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 was
primarily due to higher levels of checking fees that resulted from an increased number of noninterest-bearing checking accounts. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Securities
fees and commissions increased during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 primarily due to a continued increase in sales of fixed annuities. The decrease in securities
fees and commissions from 2001 compared with 2000 was due to lower sales of investment products, including variable annuities, largely the result of investor uncertainty regarding the stock market.
Offsetting this decline was a significant increase in fees from the sale of fixed annuities. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Insurance
income increased during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 primarily due to the continued growth in our captive reinsurance
programs. The Dime acquisition also contributed to an increase in revenues in optional insurance and property and casualty insurance products. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
growth in portfolio loan related income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 was mostly due to increased late charges on the loan portfolio, continued high loan prepayment
fees as a result of refinancing activity and the Dime acquisition. The growth in portfolio related income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 was also largely due to increased late charges and
higher loan prepayment fees. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=33,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=415992,FOLIO='31',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DM1112A.;18',USER='TCHAN',CD='14-MAR-2003;02:44' -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_do1112_1_32"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gain from other available-for-sale securities increased during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, mostly as a result of increased sales of U.S. Government
securities used as MSR risk management instruments. Gain on extinguishment of securities sold under agreements to repurchase ("repurchase agreements") decreased during the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002 compared with 2001 largely due to a reduction in terminations of certain repurchase agreements with embedded interest rate floors. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
decrease in other noninterest income during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 was primarily due to the Company's removal of the cash flow hedge designation on certain payor
swaptions which resulted in the Company reclassifying a loss of $112&nbsp;million from accumulated other comprehensive income to other noninterest income, and a reduction in some of the specific
gains realized during 2001 as described below. This overall decrease during 2002 was partially offset by a $125&nbsp;million revaluation gain on residual interests in collateralized mortgage
obligations. The increase in other income during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 was primarily due to a $55&nbsp;million revaluation gain on residual interests in collateralized mortgage
obligations, $37&nbsp;million from our bank-owned life insurance program, a $34&nbsp;million net gain from the sale of financial center stores and a gain of $32&nbsp;million on
Concord EFS,&nbsp;Inc. stock prior to its donation to the Washington Mutual Foundation. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Noninterest Expense  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Noninterest expense consisted of the following: </FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>The Company adopted Statement No. 142 on January 1, 2002, and no longer amortizes
goodwill.</FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase in employee base compensation and benefits expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 over the same period a year ago was primarily due to the acquisitions of Dime
and HomeSide, the hiring of additional staff to support our expanding operations and an increase in incentive compensation. The increase for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 over the same
period in December&nbsp;31, 2000 was primarily due to the acquisition of PNC Mortgage, Bank United and Fleet Mortgage. Full-time equivalent employees were 52,459 at December&nbsp;31,
2002 compared with 39,465 at December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 28,798 at December&nbsp;31, 2000. The Dime and HomeSide acquisitions added a total of approximately 9,000 full-time equivalent
employees. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>32</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=34,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=724884,FOLIO='32',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DO1112A.;16',USER='LSTARKE',CD='14-MAR-2003;14:44' -->
<A NAME="page_do1112_1_33"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase in occupancy and equipment expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 resulted primarily from rent, maintenance and depreciation expense related to the recent
acquisitions. A majority of the increase in occupancy and equipment expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 resulted from properties and equipment acquired from the PNC Mortgage, Bank
United and Fleet Mortgage acquisitions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase in telecommunications and outsourced information services expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 was primarily attributable to higher usage of voice and data
network services, outsourced data processing services and internet services. A significant portion of the increase in telecommunications and outsourced information services expense during the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 was attributable to higher rates, effective at the beginning of the year, with a third party service provider. Additionally, the Company added 266 and 194 financial
center stores during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001 as a result of organic growth and acquisitions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A
majority of the increase in depositor and other retail banking losses in the periods reported was due to higher loss levels per account as a result of increases in forgeries and
returned deposited items. Also contributing to this increase was the growth in new checking accounts and the number of ATMs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase in amortization of other intangible assets expense during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 was substantially due to the core deposit intangible acquired in the Dime
acquisition. Amortization of goodwill and intangible assets increased in 2001 primarily due to the PNC Mortgage, Bank United and Fleet Mortgage acquisitions. Upon adopting Statement No.&nbsp;142 at
January&nbsp;1, 2002, goodwill amortization was eliminated. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Advertising
and promotion expense increased for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 primarily due to the marketing campaign in the greater New York metropolitan area, and to a lesser
extent, due to our expansion into the metropolitan areas of Denver, Atlanta and Phoenix. The increase in advertising and promotion expense during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 was primarily
due to additional costs associated with marketing campaigns for various loan and deposit products and our expansion into new markets. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase in loan expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 was primarily due to higher non-deferred loan closing
costs, which were attributable to an overall increase in loan originations and purchases, and higher mortgage payoff expenses. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Travel
and training increased for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 primarily due to increased travel related to the 2002
acquisitions of Dime and HomeSide and the 2001 acquisitions of PNC Mortgage, Bank United and Fleet Mortgage, and the training of new employees and recently transferred employees from the
aforementioned acquisitions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A
significant portion of the increase in other expense during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 was due to increases in foreclosed assets expense, regulatory assessments, outside
printing services, business taxes and office supplies. The increase in other expense during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 was primarily due to increases in contributions to the Washington
Mutual Foundation, provision for losses on delinquent GNMA pool buy-outs and other outside services expense. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1112_review_of_financial_condition"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1112_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Review of Financial Condition    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Assets  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2002, our assets were $268.30&nbsp;billion, an increase of $25.79&nbsp;billion or 11% from $242.51&nbsp;billion at
December&nbsp;31, 2001. This increase was primarily attributable to the Dime and HomeSide acquisitions. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Upon
adopting Statement No.&nbsp;133 at January&nbsp;1, 2001, we reclassified our held-to-maturity securities to available-for-sale.
Other investment securities decreased $14,184&nbsp;million to $15,597&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $29,781&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2001, largely due to the sales of
U.S. Government and agency bonds. Refer to Note&nbsp;3 to the Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#150; "Securities" for additional information on securities, classified by security
type. </FONT></P>

<TD COLSPAN=2><FONT SIZE=2>Washington Mutual Finance</FONT></TD>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Represents loans to builders for the purpose of financing the acquisition, development and construction of single-family
residences for sale.</FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Represents construction loans made directly to the intended occupant of a single-family
residence.</FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(3)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Includes multi-family construction balances of $491 million in 2002, $385 million in 2001, $90 million in 2000, $52 million in
1999 and $16 million in 1998.</FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(4)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Includes other commercial real estate construction balances of $469 million in 2002, $608 million in 2001, $177 million in 2000,
$185 million in 1999 and $205 million in 1998.</FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=36,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=900979,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DO1112A.;16',USER='LSTARKE',CD='14-MAR-2003;14:44' -->
<A NAME="page_do1112_1_35"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase in loans held for sale in 2002 was primarily the result of higher fixed-rate loan production, which occurred due to high refinancing activity
from lower mortgage rates and the addition of the mortgage operations through the acquisitions of Dime and HomeSide in 2002. Substantially all of the increase in loans held for sale in 2001 was due to
higher fixed-rate loan production, which occurred due to lower mortgage rates and the acquisitions of Bank United, PNC Mortgage and Fleet Mortgage. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase in loans held in portfolio resulted predominantly from increases in total home loans, home equity loans and lines of credit, and multi-family loans. The increase in these
categories of loans resulted from high volumes of loan originations and purchases coupled with loans added through the Dime and HomeSide acquisitions. The increase in loans held in portfolio in 2001
was mostly due to the acquisition of Bank United. The increase in loans held in portfolio for both 2002 and 2001 was partially offset by higher levels of prepayment activity within our home loans
(excluding purchased specialty mortgage finance) portfolio. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Home,
multi-family and other commercial real estate construction loans and commercial business loans by maturity date were as follows: </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Represents loans to builders for the purpose of financing the acquisition, development and construction of single-family
residences for sale.</FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Represents construction loans made directly to the intended occupant of a single-family
residence.</FONT></DD></DL>

volume by channel was as follows: </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Includes loan refinancings entered into by both new and pre-existing loan customers.</FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Loan
volume increased during 2002 due primarily to higher refinancing activity caused by historically low mortgage rates. Purchased/correspondent loans increased during 2002 due to the
expansion of our correspondent lending activities, which was primarily due to the acquisition of Fleet Mortgage. The acquisitions of Dime and HomeSide also partly contributed to the increase.
Purchased/correspondent volume for specialty mortgage finance loans was $5.87&nbsp;billion in 2002, compared with $4.95&nbsp;billion in 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Deposits
increased to $155,516&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $107,182&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2001. Substantially all of the increase in interest-bearing
checking accounts was due to the growth in Platinum Accounts, which increased from $9.40&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2001 to $50.20&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2002. During the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, the number of Platinum Accounts increased by 549,688 from 133,557 to 683,245. As a result of the Dime acquisition, we added $15.17&nbsp;billion in deposits for
the year. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, total deposits included $25.90&nbsp;billion in custodial/escrow deposits related to loan servicing activities, compared with $10.11&nbsp;billion at
December&nbsp;31, 2001. Time deposit accounts decreased by $9.29&nbsp;billion from year-end 2001 offset by the addition of $6.10&nbsp;billion of time deposit accounts included in the
Dime acquisition. The net decrease was primarily a result of decreases in liquid certificates of deposit accounts and other certificates of deposits maturing in less than one year. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=39,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=688431,FOLIO='37',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DO1112A.;16',USER='LSTARKE',CD='14-MAR-2003;14:44' -->
<A NAME="page_do1112_1_38"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Checking
accounts, savings accounts and money market deposit accounts increased to 78% of total deposits at December&nbsp;31, 2002, compared with 66% at year-end 2001.
These products generally have the benefit of lower interest costs, compared with time deposit accounts. Even though checking, savings and money market deposits are more liquid, we consider them to be
the core relationship with our customers. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, deposits funded 58% of total assets, compared with 44% at year-end 2001. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Borrowings  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our borrowings predominantly take the form of repurchase agreements and advances from the Federal Home Loan Banks of Seattle, San Francisco, Dallas and New York.
The exact mix of these two types of wholesale borrowings at any given time is dependent upon the market pricing of the individual borrowing sources. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
wholesale borrowings decreased by $36,090&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002 compared with year-end 2001 due to a significant increase in deposits as a result of
Platinum Accounts. Other borrowings, however, increased by $2,688&nbsp;million during 2002 predominantly due to the issuance of senior and subordinated debt, and trust preferred income securities
acquired from Dime. Refer to "Liquidity" for further discussion of funding sources at December&nbsp;31, 2002, compared with year-end 2001. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1112_off-balance_sheet_arrangements"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1112_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Asset Securitization  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We transform loans into securities, which are sold to investors&nbsp;&#150; a process known as securitization. Securitization involves the sale of loans
to a qualifying special-purpose entity ("QSPE"), typically a trust. Generally, in a securitization, we transfer financial assets to QSPEs, which are legally isolated from the Company. The QSPEs, in
turn, issue interest-bearing securities, commonly called asset-backed securities, that are secured by future collections on the sold loans. The QSPE sells securities to investors, which entitle them
to receive specified cash flows during the term of the security. The QSPE uses proceeds from the sale of these securities to pay the purchase price for the sold loans. The proceeds from the issuance
of the securities are then distributed to the Company as consideration for the loans transferred. The Company has not used unconsolidated special-purpose entities as a mechanism to remove nonaccrual
loans and foreclosed assets from the balance sheet. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Securitization
is used to provide a source of liquidity and less expensive funding and also reduces our credit exposure to borrowers. As part of non-agency securitizations,
we use QSPEs to facilitate the transfer of mortgage loans into the secondary market. These entities are not consolidated within our financial statements since they satisfy the criteria established by
Statement No.&nbsp;140</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>, Accounting for the Transfers and Servicing of Financial Assets and Extinguishments of Liabilities</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. In general, these criteria
require the QSPE to be demonstrably distinct from the transferor (the Company), be limited to permitted activities, and have defined limits on the assets it can hold and the permitted sales, exchanges
or distributions of its assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
routinely securitize home, specialty home loans and commercial real estate loans into the secondary market. The allocated carrying value of loans securitized and sold during the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 was $163.60&nbsp;billion compared with $102.05&nbsp;billion in 2001. Investors and securitization trusts do not have any recourse to the Company for loans
securitized and sold during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001. When we sell or securitize loans, we generally retain the right to service the loans and may retain senior, subordinated,
residual, and other interests, all of which are considered retained interests in the securitized assets. Retained interests may provide credit enhancement to the investors and represent the Company's
maximum risk exposure associated with these transactions. Investors in the securities issued
by the QSPEs have no further recourse against the Company if cash flows generated by the securitized assets are inadequate to service the obligations of the QSPEs. Additional information concerning
securitization transactions is included in Note&nbsp;5 to the Consolidated Financial Statements&nbsp;&#150; "Mortgage Banking Activities." </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=40,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=699977,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DO1112A.;16',USER='LSTARKE',CD='14-MAR-2003;14:44' -->
<A NAME="page_do1112_1_39"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Retained
interests are recorded on the balance sheet and represent mortgage-backed securities and MSR. Retained interests in mortgage-backed securities in which the securitization has
been accounted for as a sale, were $10.78&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2002. Retained interests in MSR were $5.34&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2002. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Contractual Obligations  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table presents, as of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company's significant fixed and determinable contractual obligations, within the categories
described below, by payment date. These contractual obligations, except for the operating lease obligations, are included in the Consolidated Statements of Financial Condition. The payment amounts
represent those amounts contractually due to the recipient. </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="96%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=14 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Payments Due by Period (in millions)</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Contractual Obligations</B></FONT><BR>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Loan rate lock commitments are adjusted for rate locks which are expected to terminate prior to the time the loan is
funded.</FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company enters into derivative contracts under which the Company is required to either receive cash or pay cash to counterparties depending on changes in interest
rates. Derivative contracts are carried at fair value on the Consolidated Statements of Financial Condition with the fair value representing the net present value of expected future cash receipts or
payments based on market interest rates as of the balance sheet date. The fair value of the contracts changes daily as market interest rates change. Further discussion of derivative instruments is
included in Note&nbsp;1&nbsp;&#150; "Summary of Significant Accounting Policies" and Note&nbsp;21&nbsp;&#150; "Derivative Financial Instruments" to the Consolidated Financial
Statements. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Commitments, Guarantees and Contingencies  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company may also have liabilities under certain contractual agreements contingent upon occurrence of certain events. A discussion of significant contractual
arrangements under which the Company may be held contingently liable, including guarantee arrangements, is included in Note&nbsp;14&nbsp;&#150; "Commitments, Guarantees and Contingencies"
to the Consolidated Financial Statements. In addition,
the Company has commitments and obligations under pension and other postretirement benefit plans as described in Note&nbsp;20&nbsp;&#150; "Employee Benefits Programs and Other Expense" to
the Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=41,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=651936,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DO1112A.;16',USER='LSTARKE',CD='14-MAR-2003;14:44' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

NAME="page_dq1112_1_40"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq1112_asset_quality"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq1112_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Asset Quality    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Nonaccrual Loans, Foreclosed Assets and Restructured Loans.  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Loans are generally placed on nonaccrual status when they are 90 days or more past due or when the timely collection of the principal of the loan, in whole or in
part, is not expected. Management's classification of a loan as nonaccrual or restructured does not necessarily indicate that the principal of the loan is uncollectible in whole or in part. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Nonaccrual
loans and foreclosed assets ("nonperforming assets") and restructured loans consisted of the following: </FONT></P>

<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="38%"><FONT SIZE=2>Total nonperforming assets and restructured loans</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>2,691</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>2,376</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>1,107</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>1,083</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>1,328</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Represents
loans to builders for the purpose of financing the acquisition, development and construction of single-family residences for sale. </FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Represents
construction loans made directly to the intended occupant of a single-family residence.</FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Nonaccrual
loans increased to $2,257&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $2,030&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2001. Of the increase in nonaccrual loans during the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, approximately $106&nbsp;million was attributable to loans originated by Dime and HomeSide. These loans are concentrated in home loans as well as the commercial
business and commercial real estate loan categories. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Nonaccrual
loans held for sale, which are excluded from the nonaccrual balances presented above, were $119&nbsp;million, $123&nbsp;million, $32&nbsp;million, $30&nbsp;million and
zero at December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001, 2000, 1999 </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=42,EFW="2105105",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=427369,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK015:[03SEA2.03SEA1112]DQ1112A.;18',USER='CPULLIA',CD='13-MAR-2003;08:51' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1112_1_41"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
and 1998. Loans held for sale are accounted for at the lower of aggregate cost or market value, with valuation changes included as adjustments to gain from mortgage loans. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Home
loan nonaccrual loans (excluding purchased specialty mortgage finance) of $1,017&nbsp;million increased by $43&nbsp;million during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002.
Nonperforming loan sales, as well as continued strength in the housing market, moderated the overall increase in home loan nonaccruals. During the year, nonperforming loans sale activity reduced
nonaccrual loans by $135&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Purchased
specialty mortgage finance nonaccrual loans totaled $488&nbsp;million, an increase of $160&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. The increase was
primarily due to higher rates of unemployment, which resulted from the sluggish economy. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2002, other real estate on nonaccrual totaled $414&nbsp;million, compared with $376&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2001. Nonaccrual loans to finance
franchise-oriented businesses increased $128&nbsp;million during the year offsetting improvements in the nonresidential commercial real estate portfolio. The Company elected to discontinue its
franchise finance lending activities due to the weak performance of the convenience store segment of the business and the change in ownership of Franchise Finance Corporation of America, the source of
this portfolio. This portfolio, which includes both the fast food
and convenience store segments, totaled $633&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002. The nonaccrual loans in this portfolio have been specifically reserved. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Multi-family
loans on nonaccrual totaled $50&nbsp;million at year end, of which $5&nbsp;million was attributable to Dime and HomeSide. This portfolio continues to exhibit strong and
stable performance with nonaccrual loans in this category representing 0.28% of total multi-family loans at December&nbsp;31, 2002 compared with 0.36% at December&nbsp;31, 2001. Commercial
business nonaccrual loans decreased $21&nbsp;million during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 to $79&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2002, foreclosed assets were $336&nbsp;million, compared with $228&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2001. The Company's foreclosed assets include both home
and commercial real estate as well as a small amount of personal property. Of the $108&nbsp;million increase in 2002, $65&nbsp;million was comprised of home loan properties and $43&nbsp;million
was comprised of commercial real estate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If
interest on nonaccrual loans under the original terms had been recognized, such income is estimated to have been $134&nbsp;million in 2002, $106&nbsp;million in 2001 and
$66&nbsp;million in 2000. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<A NAME="page_dq1112_1_42"> </A>
<BR>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Represents
loans to builders for the purpose of financing the acquisition, development and construction of single-family residences for sale. </FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1>Represents
construction loans made directly to the intended occupant of a single-family residence. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT></P>
